projects.spatial.trees

Class PRQuadTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.spatial.trees.PRQuadTree
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SpatialDictionary

    public class PRQuadTree
extends java.lang.Object
implements SpatialDictionary

    PRQuadTree implements Point-Region (P-R) QuadTrees. Those are trie-based decompositions of 2D space which, unlike KDTrees or Point QuadTrees, is not generated by the data points, but is decided in advance based on decomposing a 2^n * 2^n space at successively smaller powers of 2.

    Because PR-QuadTrees are 4-ary instead of binary trees, they can offer better search efficiency than KD-Trees. On the other hand, points very close to each other can cause many recursive decompositions for just two points. This can negatively impact search locally in the tree.

    PR-QuadTrees are also not particularly easy to generalize to other dimensions, because the fan-out of every nodes is 2^d, for dimensionality d of the space that is indexed. For just 10 dimensions, we already have more than 1000 children subtrees per nodes. The course staff has come around some papers with applications of oct-trees, which are extensions of PR-QuadTrees) in 3 * dimensions. Beyond 3, it seems that the idea of such exponential fanout trie-based quadtrees fades.

    YOU SHOULD ***NOT*** EDIT THIS CLASS! If you do, you risk not passing our tests! All the functionality of the P-R QuadTree will be implemented by the various PRQuadNodes.

    Author:
    Jason Filippou

    • Field Detail

      • root

        private PRQuadNode root
        Our root is a PRQuadNode. If null, it is assumed to be a white nodes.

      • bucketingParam

        private int bucketingParam
        The bucketing parameter which globally controls how many KDPoints

      • k

        private int k
        n defines the area spanned by the root: 2^n * 2^n, with the origin (0,0) assumed to be the bottom left corner. This means that the centroid has coordinates (2^(n-1), 2^(n-1))

      • count

        private int count
        The number of KDPoints held by the PRQuadTree. Note that, unlike KD-Trees, in PR-QuadTrees, the number of nodes is not (necessarily) equal to the number of points stored.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PRQuadTree

        public PRQuadTree(int k,
                  int bucketingParam)
        Constructor for PRQuadTree objects.
        Parameters:
        k - The exponent of 2 that defines the area assumed to be spanned by the entire QuadTree (i.e by its root node). Remember that, as in class, this means that the centroid of the original quadrant would be implicitly stored at (0, 0), and when we split for the first time, the cross (+) centered in (0, 0) would define 4 centroids: The top-right corner would be at ( 2^(k-1), 2^(k-1) ), the bottom-right at ( 2^(k-1), -2 ^(k-1)), etc. For example, if this parameter is given as 5, the top-right corner of the modeled space would have cartesian cooordinates (16, 16), the bottom-right (16, -16) and so on and so forth. This also allows for the insertion of KDPoints with negative coordinates: this is completely fine. Recall the discussions that we have had in class and Piazza about KDPoints that lie exactly on the sides of the quadrants that our quadtree will recursively produce!
        bucketingParam - The "bucketing" parameter, which controls how many KDPoints a PRQuadBlackNode of this tree can hold before having to split.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if bucketingParam < 1
        See Also:
        k, bucketingParam

      • height

        public int height()
        Description copied from interface: SpatialDictionary

        Return the height of the SpatialDictionary. The height is defined similarly to AVL trees, as follows:

        1. The height of a null tree (no nodes) is -1 (minus 1).
        2. The height of a tree that consists of a single nodes (a "stub" tree) is 0 (zero).
        3. The height of a tree that consists of four children is the maximum height of its children plus one.
        Specified by:
        height in interface SpatialDictionary
        Returns:
        the height of the subtree rooted at the current node.

        Description copied from interface: SpatialDictionary

        Specified by:

        Returns:
        true iff SpatialDictionary.count() == 0, false otherwise.
